name: link
description: A physical link with inertia, collision, and visual properties. A link must be a child of a model, and any number of links may exist in a model.

children.name: name
children.description: A unique name for the link within the scope of the model.

children.name: gravity
children.description: If true, the link is affected by gravity.

children.name: enable_wind
children.description: If true, the link is affected by the wind.

children.name: self_collide
children.description: If true, the link can collide with other links in the model. Two links within a model will collide if link1.self_collide OR link2.self_collide. Links connected by a joint will never collide.

children.name: kinematic
children.description: If true, the link is kinematic only. A kinematic link does not react to forces such as gravity, applied force / torque, or influences from other dynamic bodies. The link can be animated by changing its position or velocity. Kinematic links can also be connected by joints, and moved by joint position or velocity commands.

children.name: must_be_base_link
children.description: If true, the link will have 6DOF and be a direct child of world.

children.name: velocity_decay
children.description: Exponential damping of the link's velocity.

children.name: linear
children.description: Linear damping

children.name: angular
children.description: Angular damping

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: inertial
children.description: The link's mass, position of its center of mass, its central inertia properties, and optionally its fluid added mass.

children.name: auto
children.description: Set to true if you want automatic computation for the moments of inertia (ixx, iyy, izz) and products of inertia(ixy, iyz, ixz). Default value is false.

children.name: mass
children.description: The mass of the link.

children.name: density
children.description: Mass Density of the collision geometry. This is used to determine mass and inertia values during automatic calculation. This density value would be overwritten by the density value in collision. Default is the density of water 1000 kg/m^3.

children.name: auto_inertia_params
children.description: Parent tag to hold user-defined custom params for mesh inertia calculator The elements used under this would be overwritten by the elements in auto_inertia_params in collision.

children.name: pose
children.description: This pose (translation, rotation) describes the position and orientation of the link's center-of-mass-frame C relative to the link-frame L. The first three components (x y z) specify the position vector from Lo (the link-frame origin) to Co (the link's center of mass) as `x L̂x + y L̂y + z L̂ᴢ`, where L̂x, L̂y, L̂ᴢ are link-frame L's orthogonal unit vectors. The subsequent values characterize C's orientation relative to link-frame L as a sequence of Euler rotations (r p y) documented in http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x y z w), where w is the scalar component.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: inertia
children.description: This link's moments of inertia ixx, iyy, izz and products of inertia ixy, ixz, iyz about Co (the link's center of mass) for the unit vectors Ĉx, Ĉy, Ĉᴢ fixed in the center-of-mass-frame C. Note: the orientation of Ĉx, Ĉy, Ĉᴢ relative to L̂x, L̂y, L̂ᴢ is specified by the `pose` tag. To avoid compatibility issues associated with the negative sign convention for product of inertia, align Ĉx, Ĉy, Ĉᴢ with principal inertia directions so that all the products of inertia are zero. For more information about this sign convention, see the following MathWorks documentation for working with CAD tools: https://www.mathworks.com/help/releases/R2021b/physmod/sm/ug/specify-custom-inertia.html#mw_b043ec69-835b-4ca9-8769-af2e6f1b190c

children.name: ixx
children.description: The link's moment of inertia about Co (the link's center of mass) for Ĉx.

children.name: ixy
children.description: The link's product of inertia about Co (the link's center of mass) for Ĉx and Ĉy, where the product of inertia convention -m x y (not +m x y) is used. If Ĉx or Ĉy is a principal inertia direction, ixy = 0.

children.name: ixz
children.description: The link's product of inertia about Co (the link's center of mass) for Ĉx and Ĉz, where the product of inertia convention -m x z (not +m x z) is used. If Ĉx or Ĉz is a principal inertia direction, ixz = 0.

children.name: iyy
children.description: The link's moment of inertia about Co (the link's center of mass) for Ĉy.

children.name: iyz
children.description: The link's product of inertia about Co (the link's center of mass) for Ĉy and Ĉz, where the product of inertia convention -m y z (not +m y z) is used. If Ĉy or Ĉz is a principal inertia direction, iyz = 0.

children.name: izz
children.description: The link's moment of inertia about Co (the link's center of mass) for Ĉz.

children.name: fluid_added_mass
children.description: This link's fluid added mass matrix about the link's origin. This matrix represents the inertia of the fluid that is dislocated when the body moves. Added mass should be zero if the density of the surrounding fluid is negligible with respect to the body's density. The 6x6 matrix is symmetric, therefore only 21 unique elements can be set. The elements of the matrix follow the [x, y, z, p, q, r] notation, where [x, y, z] correspond to translation and [p, q, r] to rotation (i.e. roll, pitch, yaw).

children.name: xx
children.description: Added mass in the X axis due to linear acceleration in the X axis, in kg.

children.name: xy
children.description: Added mass in the X axis due to linear acceleration in the Y axis, and vice-versa, in kg.

children.name: xz
children.description: Added mass in the X axis due to linear acceleration in the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg.

children.name: xp
children.description: Added mass in the X axis due to angular acceleration about the X axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: xq
children.description: Added mass in the X axis due to angular acceleration about the Y axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: xr
children.description: Added mass in the X axis due to angular acceleration about the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: yy
children.description: Added mass in the Y axis due to linear acceleration in the Y axis, in kg.

children.name: yz
children.description: Added mass in the Y axis due to linear acceleration in the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg.

children.name: yp
children.description: Added mass in the Y axis due to angular acceleration about the X axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: yq
children.description: Added mass in the Y axis due to angular acceleration about the Y axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: yr
children.description: Added mass in the Y axis due to angular acceleration about the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: zz
children.description: Added mass in the Z axis due to linear acceleration in the Z axis, in kg.

children.name: zp
children.description: Added mass in the Z axis due to angular acceleration about the X axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: zq
children.description: Added mass in the Z axis due to angular acceleration about the Y axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: zr
children.description: Added mass in the Z axis due to angular acceleration about the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m.

children.name: pp
children.description: Added mass moment about the X axis due to angular acceleration about the X axis, in kg * m^2.

children.name: pq
children.description: Added mass moment about the X axis due to angular acceleration about the Y axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m^2.

children.name: pr
children.description: Added mass moment about the X axis due to angular acceleration about the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m^2.

children.name: qq
children.description: Added mass moment about the Y axis due to angular acceleration about the Y axis, in kg * m^2.

children.name: qr
children.description: Added mass moment about the Y axis due to angular acceleration about the Z axis, and vice-versa, in kg * m^2.

children.name: rr
children.description: Added mass moment about the Z axis due to angular acceleration about the Z axis, in kg * m^2.

children.name: collision
children.description: The collision properties of a link. Note that this can be different from the visual properties of a link, for example, simpler collision models are often used to reduce computation time.

children.name: visual
children.description: The visual properties of the link. This element specifies the shape of the object (box, cylinder, etc.) for visualization purposes.

children.name: sensor
children.description: The sensor tag describes the type and properties of a sensor.

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the projector

children.name: texture
children.description: Texture name

children.name: fov
children.description: Field of view

children.name: near_clip
children.description: Near clip distance

children.name: far_clip
children.description: far clip distance

children.name: visibility_flags
children.description: Visibility flags of a projector. When (camera's visibility_mask & projector's visibility_flags) evaluates to non-zero, the projector will be visible to the camera.

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: plugin
children.description: A plugin is a dynamically loaded chunk of code. It can exist as a child of world, model, and sensor.

children.name: name
children.description: A name for the plugin.

children.name: filename
children.description: Name of the shared library to load. If the filename is not a full path name, the file will be searched for in the configuration paths.

children.name: Elements
children.description: Arbitrary elements and attributes that can be used to configure the plugin

children.name: audio_sink
children.description: An audio sink.

children.name: audio_source
children.description: An audio source.

children.name: uri
children.description: URI of the audio media.

children.name: pitch
children.description: Pitch for the audio media, in Hz

children.name: gain
children.description: Gain for the audio media, in dB.

children.name: contact
children.description: List of collision objects that will trigger audio playback.

children.name: collision
children.description: Name of child collision element that will trigger audio playback.

children.name: loop
children.description: True to make the audio source loop playback.

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: battery
children.description: Description of a battery.

children.name: name
children.description: Unique name for the battery.

children.name: voltage
children.description: Initial voltage in volts.

children.name: light
children.description: The light element describes a light source.

children.name: particle_emitter
children.description: A particle emitter that can be used to describe fog, smoke, and dust.

children.name: name
children.description: A unique name for the particle emitter.

children.name: type
children.description: The type of a particle emitter. One of "box", "cylinder", "ellipsoid", or "point".

children.name: emitting
children.description: True indicates that the particle emitter should generate particles when loaded

children.name: duration
children.description: The number of seconds the emitter is active. A value less than or equal to zero means infinite duration.

children.name: size
children.description: The size of the emitter where the particles are sampled. Default value is (1, 1, 1). Note that the interpretation of the emitter area varies depending on the emmiter type: - point: The area is ignored. - box: The area is interpreted as width X height X depth. - cylinder: The area is interpreted as the bounding box of the cylinder. The cylinder is oriented along the Z-axis. - ellipsoid: The area is interpreted as the bounding box of an ellipsoid shaped area, i.e. a sphere or squashed-sphere area. The parameters are again identical to EM_BOX, except that the dimensions describe the widest points along each of the axes.

children.name: particle_size
children.description: The particle dimensions (width, height, depth).

children.name: lifetime
children.description: The number of seconds each particle will ’live’ for before being destroyed. This value must be greater than zero.

children.name: rate
children.description: The number of particles per second that should be emitted.

children.name: min_velocity
children.description: Sets a minimum velocity for each particle (m/s).

children.name: max_velocity
children.description: Sets a maximum velocity for each particle (m/s).

children.name: scale_rate
children.description: Sets the amount by which to scale the particles in both x and y direction per second.

children.name: color_start
children.description: Sets the starting color for all particles emitted. The actual color will be interpolated between this color and the one set under color_end. Color::White is the default color for the particles unless a specific function is used. To specify a color, RGB values should be passed in. For example, to specify red, a user should enter:

children.name: color_end
children.description: Sets the end color for all particles emitted. The actual color will be interpolated between this color and the one set under color_start. Color::White is the default color for the particles unless a specific function is used (see color_start for more information about defining custom colors with RGB values). Note that this function overrides the particle colors set with color_range_image.

children.name: color_range_image
children.description: Sets the path to the color image used as an affector. This affector modifies the color of particles in flight. The colors are taken from a specified image file. The range of color values begins from the left side of the image and moves to the right over the lifetime of the particle, therefore only the horizontal dimension of the image is used. Note that this function overrides the particle colors set with color_start and color_end.

children.name: topic
children.description: Topic used to update particle emitter properties at runtime. The default topic is /model/{model_name}/particle_emitter/{emitter_name} Note that the emitter id and name may not be changed.

children.name: particle_scatter_ratio
children.description: This is used to determine the ratio of particles that will be detected by sensors. Increasing the ratio means there is a higher chance of particles reflecting and interfering with depth sensing, making the emitter appear more dense. Decreasing the ratio decreases the chance of particles reflecting and interfering with depth sensing, making it appear less dense.

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: material
children.description: The material of the visual element.

children.name: script
children.description: Name of material from an installed script file. This will override the color element if the script exists.

children.name: uri
children.description: URI of the material script file

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the script within the script file

children.name: type
children.description: vertex, pixel, normal_map_object_space, normal_map_tangent_space

children.name: normal_map
children.description: filename of the normal map

children.name: render_order
children.description: Set render order for coplanar polygons. The higher value will be rendered on top of the other coplanar polygons

children.name: lighting
children.description: If false, dynamic lighting will be disabled

children.name: ambient
children.description: The ambient color of a material specified by set of four numbers representing red/green/blue, each in the range of [0,1].

children.name: diffuse
children.description: The diffuse color of a material specified by set of four numbers representing red/green/blue/alpha, each in the range of [0,1].

children.name: specular
children.description: The specular color of a material specified by set of four numbers representing red/green/blue/alpha, each in the range of [0,1].

children.name: shininess
children.description: The specular exponent of a material

children.name: emissive
children.description: The emissive color of a material specified by set of four numbers representing red/green/blue, each in the range of [0,1].

children.name: double_sided
children.description: If true, the mesh that this material is applied to will be rendered as double sided

children.name: pbr
children.description: Physically Based Rendering (PBR) material. There are two PBR workflows: metal and specular. While both workflows and their parameters can be specified at the same time, typically only one of them will be used (depending on the underlying renderer capability). It is also recommended to use the same workflow for all materials in the world.

children.name: metal
children.description: PBR using the Metallic/Roughness workflow.

children.name: albedo_map
children.description: Filename of the diffuse/albedo map.

children.name: roughness_map
children.description: Filename of the roughness map.

children.name: roughness
children.description: Material roughness in the range of [0,1], where 0 represents a smooth surface and 1 represents a rough surface. This is the inverse of a specular map in a PBR specular workflow.

children.name: metalness_map
children.description: Filename of the metalness map.

children.name: metalness
children.description: Material metalness in the range of [0,1], where 0 represents non-metal and 1 represents raw metal

children.name: environment_map
children.description: Filename of the environment / reflection map, typically in the form of a cubemap

children.name: ambient_occlusion_map
children.description: Filename of the ambient occlusion map. The map defines the amount of ambient lighting on the surface.

children.name: normal_map
children.description: Filename of the normal map. The normals can be in the object space or tangent space as specified in the 'type' attribute

children.name: type
children.description: The space that the normals are in. Values are: 'object' or 'tangent'

children.name: emissive_map
children.description: Filename of the emissive map.

children.name: light_map
children.description: Filename of the light map. The light map is a prebaked light texture that is applied over the albedo map

children.name: uv_set
children.description: Index of the texture coordinate set to use.

children.name: specular
children.description: PBR using the Specular/Glossiness workflow.

children.name: albedo_map
children.description: Filename of the diffuse/albedo map.

children.name: specular_map
children.description: Filename of the specular map.

children.name: glossiness_map
children.description: Filename of the glossiness map.

children.name: glossiness
children.description: Material glossiness in the range of [0-1], where 0 represents a rough surface and 1 represents a smooth surface. This is the inverse of a roughness map in a PBR metal workflow.

children.name: environment_map
children.description: Filename of the environment / reflection map, typically in the form of a cubemap

children.name: ambient_occlusion_map
children.description: Filename of the ambient occlusion map. The map defines the amount of ambient lighting on the surface.

children.name: normal_map
children.description: Filename of the normal map. The normals can be in the object space or tangent space as specified in the 'type' attribute

children.name: type
children.description: The space that the normals are in. Values are: 'object' or 'tangent'

children.name: emissive_map
children.description: Filename of the emissive map.

children.name: light_map
children.description: Filename of the light map. The light map is a prebaked light texture that is applied over the albedo map

children.name: uv_set
children.description: Index of the texture coordinate set to use.
